Here we provide the proof of part 2 of Theorem \ref{prop:4}, i.e., $v_G^T K^{-1} u_R<0$ and $v_{{\widehat} G}^T {\widehat} K^{-1} u_{{\widehat} R}<0$.
 The proof is based on an argument
of accessibility for the states of the doubly infinite  QBD.
Assumptions \ref{a:zero} and \ref{a:one},   together imply that ${\mathcal{S}}_* = {\mathcal{S}}$ and so we have
the following property.\smallskip


\noindent 
{\bf A.1}  For any $i,j\in{\mathcal{S}}$, for any level
 $k$ and $k'$, there is a path from $(k,i)$ to $(k',j)$.


We prove that $v_G^T K^{-1} u_R<0$; the proof that $v_{{\widehat} G}^T {\widehat} K^{-1} u_{{\widehat} R}<0$ is similar and is left to the reader.
For the sake of simplicity we write $u$ in place of $u_R$ and $v$ in place of $v_G$.
The proof consists in analyzing the sign properties of the components
of the vectors $u$ and $-K^{-1}u$, and relies on the irreducibility assumptions. 

\paragraph{The vector $u$}
\label{sec:vector-u}
\  \\
{\it Case 1.}  $R$ is irreducible.  Then $u > 0$, and $K^{-1} u < 0$ also, so that $v^T K^{-1} u  < 0$.

\noindent
{\it Case 2.}  $R$ is reducible.  
\quad
We need to define various subsets of the set of phases ${\mathcal{S}} = \{1, \ldots, n\}$.  The most
important ones define  a partition of ${\mathcal{S}}$ into the four subsets
${\mathcal{S}}_1$, ${\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_1$, ${\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_b$ and ${\mathcal{S}}_a$ that we define later.
As we assume that the matrix $A$ is irreducible, we have after a
suitable permutation of rows and columns
$\left[\begin{smallmatrix}R_1 & R_{12} \\ 0 & R_2\end{smallmatrix}\right]$,
where $R_1$ is irreducible and $R_2$ is strictly upper-triangular.
The proof is in \cite[Theorem 7.2.2, page 154]{lr99}. 
The rows and columns of $R_1$ are indexed by ${\mathcal{S}}_1$ and those of $R_2$
are indexed by ${\mathcal{S}}_2$, and so
$
{\mathcal{S}} = {\mathcal{S}}_1 \cup {\mathcal{S}}_2.
$  
By
Assumption \ref{a:one}, ${\mathcal{S}}_1$ is not empty.

Concerning the eigenvector $u$ of $R$, we have : $u_i > 0$ for any $i$
in ${\mathcal{S}}_1$ and $u_i=0$ for $i$ in ${\mathcal{S}}_2$.  The physical meaning of the
partition ${\mathcal{S}} = {\mathcal{S}}_1 \cup {\mathcal{S}}_2$ is given below.  Consider the doubly
infinite QBD process.
\smallskip 

\noindent
{\bf B.1.} For any $i\in{\mathcal{S}}_1$, for any level $k$, for any displacement
$h \geq 1$, there exists $i'\in{\mathcal{S}}_1$ such that there is a path from
$(k,i)$ to $(k+h, i')$ avoiding level $k$ and the levels below.
\smallskip

\noindent
{\bf B.2.} For any $i\in{\mathcal{S}}_2$, for any level $k$, for any displacement
$h \geq 1$, for any $i'\in{\mathcal{S}}_1$, there is no path from $(k,i)$ to
$(k+h,i')$ avoiding level $k$;  i.e.,
any path from $(k,i)$ to $(k+h,i')$ has to go through level $k$ or $k-1$.


\paragraph{The vector $K^{-1}u$}
\label{sec:vector--k}
\ 

\noindent
The matrix $-K^{-1}$ is about transitions within a level $k$ without
visiting level $k-1$: $(-K^{-1})_{ij}$ is the expected number of
visits to $(k,j)$, starting from $(k,i)$ before any visit to level
$k-1$.  Clearly, 
\smallskip

\noindent
{\bf C.1.} $(-K^{-1})_{ij}>0$ if and only if there exists a path from
$(k,i)$ to $(k,j)$ that avoids level $k-1$, possibly after visiting some
states in level $k+1$ or above.
\smallskip

Define $w = -K^{-1} u$.  We have $w \geq u$, so that $w_i >0$ for all
$i$ in ${\mathcal{S}}_1$.  Furthermore, there may be some phases $i$ in ${\mathcal{S}}_2$
such that $w_i>0$; define ${\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_1$ as the subset of phases $i$ such
that $u_i=0$, $w_i>0$, and define ${\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_2 = {\mathcal{S}}_2 \setminus {\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_1$,
thus
$
{\mathcal{S}}_2 = {\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_1 \cup {\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_2
$. \smallskip

\noindent
{\em Case 1.} $w_i > 0$ for all $i$, i.e., ${\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_2$ is
empty.  Then, $v^T w >0$ and we are done.\smallskip

\noindent
{\em Case 2.} The set ${\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_2$ is not empty, there are phases
$i$ such that $w_i =0$.  From B.1, B.2 and C.1, we find that the
physical meaning is as follows.\smallskip

\noindent
{\bf D.1.} 
For any $i\in{\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_1$, for any level $k$, for any displacement $h \geq 1$, there exists $i'\in{\mathcal{S}}_1$ such that there is a path from $(k,i)$ to $(k+h, i')$ avoiding level $k-1$ and any level below.
\smallskip

\noindent
{\bf D.2.}
For any phase $i\in{\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_2$, for any level $k$, for any
displacement $h \geq 0$, for any $i'\in{\mathcal{S}}_1$, there is no path from
$(k,i)$ to $(k+h,i')$ avoiding level $k-1$.


\paragraph{The product $v^T K^{-1} u$}
\label{sec:product--vt}
\ 

\noindent
By \cite[Theorem 7.2.1, page 152]{lr99}, we have after a suitable
permutation of rows and columns
$
G =\left[\begin{smallmatrix}G_a & 0 \\  G_{ba} & G_b\end{smallmatrix}\right]
$
where $G_a$ is irreducible and $G_b$ is strictly lower triangular.
The rows and columns of $G_a$ are indexed by ${\mathcal{S}}_a$ and those of $G_b$
are indexed by ${\mathcal{S}}_b$; define $n_b=|{\mathcal{S}}_b|$,
thus,
$
{\mathcal{S}} = {\mathcal{S}}_a \cup {\mathcal{S}}_b.
$  
The left eigenvector $v$ of $G$ is such that $v_i > 0$ for $i$ in
${\mathcal{S}}_a$ and $v_i=0$ for $i$ in~${\mathcal{S}}_b$

By Assumption
\ref{a:one}, ${\mathcal{S}}_a$ is not empty.  The physical
interpretation is as follows.\smallskip

\noindent
{\bf E.1.}
For all $i\in{\mathcal{S}}_a$, there is $i'\in{\mathcal{S}}_a$ such that there is a path from $(k,i)$ to
  $(k-1,i')$, avoiding level $k-1$ at the intermediary steps,
  independently of $k$.
\smallskip

\noindent
{\bf E.2.}
For all $i\in{\mathcal{S}}_a$, for all $i'\in{\mathcal{S}}_b$, there is no path from $(k,i)$ to
  $(k-1,i')$, avoiding level $k-1$ at the intermediary steps,
  independently of $k$.

Now, let us assume that $v^T K^{-1} u =0$.   This implies that 
if $v_i >0$, then $w_i =0$, so that ${\mathcal{S}}_a \subseteq {\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_2$, with the
possibility that ${\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_b$, defined as 
${\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_b = {\mathcal{S}}_b \setminus({\mathcal{S}}_1
\cup {\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_1) = {\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_2 \setminus {\mathcal{S}}_a,$
 may be empty or not empty.   In summary, we have the table

\begin{center}
  \begin{tabular}{c|cccc}
 & ${\mathcal{S}}_1$ & ${\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_1$ & ${\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_b$ & ${\mathcal{S}}_a$  \\
\hline
$u$ & $u_i >0$ & $u_i =0$ & $u_i=0$ & $u_i =0$ \\
$w$ & $w_i >0$ & $w_i >0$ & $w_i=0$ & $w_i =0$  \\
$v$   & $v_i =0$ & $v_i =0$ & $v_i=0$ & $v_i >0$
  \end{tabular}
\end{center}
where ${\mathcal{S}}_1$ and ${\mathcal{S}}_a$ are not empty, and we have
$
{\mathcal{S}}_2 = {\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_1 \cup {\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_b \cup {\mathcal{S}}_a,   ~ 
{\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_2 = {\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_b \cup {\mathcal{S}}_a,   ~
{\mathcal{S}}_b = {\mathcal{S}}_1 \cup {\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_1 \cup {\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_b
$.

Now, let us fix some arbitrary initial level $k_0$ and take any phase
$i$ in ${\mathcal{S}}_a$.
Since ${\mathcal{S}}_a \subset {\widetilde}{\mathcal{S}}_2$, we know by D.2 that any path
from $(k,i)$ to any state $(k+h,j)$ with $h \geq 0$ and $j$ in ${\mathcal{S}}_1$ must pass through level $k-1$.
By E.1 and E.2, from the state $(k,i)$, the first state $(k-1,i')$ on
any path through level $k-1$ is such that $i'$ is in ${\mathcal{S}}_a$.
Therefore, we know that any path from $(k,i)$ to any state $(k-1+h,
j)$ with $h \geq 0$ and $j$ in ${\mathcal{S}}_1$ must pass through level $k-2$.
We repeat the argument, and find that there is no path from ${\mathbb{Z}}
\times {\mathcal{S}}_a$ to
any state in ${\mathbb{Z}} \times {\mathcal{S}}_1$.   
This contradicts the property {A.1}.
